title: Researchers use quantum computing to predict gene relationships
description: In a new multidisciplinary study, researchers at Texas A&M University showed how quantum computing—a new kind of computing that can process additional types of data—can assist with genetic research and used it to discover new links between genes that scientists were previously unable to detect.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Study highlights importance of not investigating exon splicing in isolation
description: A study published in the journal Function highlights the importance of not investigating exon splicing in isolation. Exon splicing is the process by which introns are removed from pre-mRNA and exons are spliced back together.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Blasts to clear World War II munitions could contaminate the ocean
description: World War II concluded decades ago, but live mines lurking on the ocean floor still pose threats, potentially spewing unexpected geysers or releasing contaminants into the water. Experts conduct controlled explosions to clear underwater munitions, but concerns have arisen over the environmental impacts of these blasts.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Study: Consumers, florists differ on floral arrangements
description: Consumer preferences in floral arrangements don't necessarily match the designs that florists are taught to make, according to a new study by researchers at North Carolina State University.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: In 2024, Space Coast gears up for most astronaut launches since '09
description: The business of sending humans into space has not yet risen to the levels seen during the space shuttle program, but 2024 could see the most U.S.-based orbital launches in 15 years.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Q&A: To save the planet's glaciers, human actions still matter, says scientist
description: Climate change is melting glaciers around the world. Vanishing ice means less water for the millions of people relying on it and threatens the habitats of species—from bacteria to plants and fish—that live in glacier-fed ecosystems.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Voters reject culture war tactics in school board elections
description: Diversity and inclusion programs, book bans, censorship and debates over school curricula are all signs that America's culture wars have moved into a new combat zone: school boards.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New research demonstrates more effective method for measuring impact of scientific publications
description: Newly published research reexamines the evaluation of scientific findings, proposing a network-based methodology for contextualizing a publication's impact.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Archaeologists discover long-lost Scottish monastery
description: A team of archaeologists, co-led by a researcher at the University of Southampton, believe they have located the site of the lost Monastery of Deer in Northeast Scotland.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: 400-year-old mystery of why early explosive produces purple smoke solved by academics
description: Scientists at the University of Bristol have discovered why fulminating gold—the world's first known high explosive—produces a purple smoke when it detonates, solving a 400-year-old alchemy puzzle.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Food waste study: 18 billion animals a year die, but never end up on our plate
description: Each year, a staggering 18 billion chickens, turkeys, pigs, sheep, goats, and cows either die or are killed without making it onto someone's plate. Environmental scientists Juliane Klaura, Laura Scherer, and Gerard Breeman were the first to calculate this number on a global scale. "Reducing these numbers would not only prevent unnecessary animal suffering but also contribute to the fight against climate change."
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Examining US golf courses' nutrient use and management tactics
description: Nutrient use on United States golf courses increases management costs and has the potential to influence ecosystems. Therefore, assessing nutrient use and management practices is critical to developing and teaching the best management practices. The objectives of this survey were to measure nutrient use and management practices on United States golf courses in 2021 and to determine if changes occurred since 2006.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New psychology study unearths ways to bolster global climate awareness and climate action
description: An international team of scientists has created a tool that can aid in increasing climate awareness and climate action globally by highlighting messaging themes shown to be effective through experimental research.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Unlocking the secrets of chimerism: Plastid genes and the quest for variegation in the ornamental plant market
description: The global indoor plant market is burgeoning, with projections of reaching $7.27 billion by 2025. Chimeric plants, first noted in the 17th century, have become popular for their distinctive variegated patterns. These patterns are a product of the structure and development of the plant's shoot apical meristem (SAM).
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Analysis of cyberstalking research identifies factors associated with perpetration, victimization
description: The widespread use of digital technologies and the Internet has spurred a new type of personal intrusion, known as cyberstalking. Incidences of cyberstalking have risen, with the U.S. Department of Justice estimating that more than 1.3 million people experience this type of victimization annually. A new study has explored research to identify the factors associated with perpetration and victimization in cyberstalking. The study's findings can inform the development of efforts to prevent and address cyberstalking.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Looking for lithium-bearing pegmatites
description: The commercial importance of lithium is ever-growing, and its production is globally dominated by lithium-cesium-tantalum (LCT) pegmatites. These are spectacular rocks featuring impressive ultra-coarse textures, but they are very elusive due to a combination of factors: they are small, and until a decade ago, they were often regarded as nothing more than a geological curiosity. As a result, our knowledge of LCT pegmatites from an exploration standpoint is limited, which makes them hard to find.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Study reveals new clues about how whales and dolphins came to use echolocation
description: A study published in Diversity provides new insight into how toothed whales and dolphins came to navigate the underwater world using sound waves.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: From 2D to 3D: MXene's path to revolutionizing energy storage and more
description: With a slew of impressive properties, transition metal carbides, generally referred to as MXenes, are exciting nanomaterials being explored in the energy storage sector. MXenes are two-dimensional materials that consist of flakes as thin as a few nanometers.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Almost one in ten Australian men have committed a sexual offense against children, study finds
description: This report contains material that references child abuse. Readers may find the content confronting or disturbing.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Q&A: When it comes to Israel-Hamas war videos, don't always trust what you see
description: Flip through TikTok, Instagram or X (formerly Twitter) each day, and a barrage of grainy, chaotic videos paints a complicated picture of the Israel-Hamas war.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Juice burns hard toward first-ever Earth–moon flyby
description: On 17 November 2023, ESA's Juice spacecraft carried out one of the largest and most important maneuvers in its eight-year journey to Jupiter.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: AI finds formula for how to predict monster waves by using 700 years' worth of data
description: Long considered myth, freakishly large rogue waves are very real and can split apart ships and even damage oil rigs. Using 700 years' worth of wave data from more than a billion waves, scientists at the University of Copenhagen and University of Victoria have used artificial intelligence to find a formula for how to predict the occurrence of these maritime monsters. The new knowledge can make shipping safer.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Study investigates why students seek international experience
description: Why do students want to go abroad for a semester or take part in international conferences? A new study by the University of Würzburg has investigated this question and the results offer recommendations for an internationalization strategy. The research is published in Andragoška spoznanja (link to PDF in English).
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Study examines how massive 2022 eruption changed stratosphere chemistry and dynamics
description: When the Hunga Tonga-Hunga Ha'apai volcano erupted on January 15, 2022 in the South Pacific, it produced a shock wave felt around the world and triggered tsunamis in Tonga, Fiji, New Zealand, Japan, Chile, Peru and the United States.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: NASA's 'flawless' heat shield demo passes the test
description: A little more than a year ago, a NASA flight test article came screaming back from space at more than 18,000 mph, reaching temperatures of nearly 2,700°F before gently splashing down in the Pacific Ocean. At that moment, it became the largest blunt body—a type of reentry vehicle that creates a heat-deflecting shockwave—ever to reenter Earth's atmosphere.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Feeding dogs raw meat increases the risk of antibiotic-resistant E. coli, finds study
description: Feeding dogs raw (uncooked) meat increases their risk of excreting E. coli that cannot be killed by a widely used antibiotic—ciprofloxacin—researchers at the University of Bristol have found from a study of 600 healthy pet dogs.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Urban agriculture study seeks to alleviate Glasgow's 'food deserts'
description: A fresh approach to urban agriculture could help Glasgow's 'food deserts' flourish into sources of healthy, affordable produce to help reduce inequality, new research suggests.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Physiological and archaeological evidence rewrites assumptions about a gendered division of labor in prehistoric times
description: Prehistoric men hunted; prehistoric women gathered. At least this is the standard narrative written by and about men to the exclusion of women.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Exploring policies to reduce child poverty and child maltreatment
description: In a recent study, researchers have conducted a scoping review of previous studies to explore the effects of policy changes on child poverty rates. The study conducted an empirical analysis to estimate the relationship between child poverty rates and child maltreatment report (CMR) rates using national county-level data.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Study highlights need for increased transparency, precision in estimation of costs associated with biological invasions
description: Numerous studies have analyzed the financial implications associated with the control and impact of invasive alien species. The varied methodologies employed in assessing the monetary costs, the diverse categories of costs reported, and the varying spatial scopes of these evaluations raise questions about the accuracy of the reported financial figures.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: The universe can't hide behind the Zone of Avoidance any longer
description: Our view of the cosmos is always limited by the fact we are located within a galaxy filled with interstellar gas and dust. This is most dramatically seen in the central region of the Milky Way, which is filled with so much dust that it is sometimes referred to as the Zone of Avoidance. Within this zone, our observations of extragalactic objects are limited, but that is starting to change.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Dung beetle iDNA as an additional tool for biodiversity assessment
description: Many dung beetles use mammalian feces as a food source and build and relocate dung balls to lay eggs and shelter their larvae. This behavior provides many ecosystem services including nutrient cycling, secondary seed dispersal, soil excavation, and parasite and pest control.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: In many major crop regions, workers plant and harvest in spiraling heat and humidity
description: A global study of major crops has found that farmworkers are being increasingly exposed to combinations of extreme heat and humidity during planting and harvest seasons that can make it hard for them to function. Such conditions have nearly doubled across the world since 1979, the authors report, a trend that could eventually hinder cultivation.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Myths about plastic pollution are leading to public confusion: Here's why
description: Does the prediction that there could be "more plastic than fish in the ocean by 2050" concern you? How about reports that "we eat a credit card's worth of plastic per week"? These are some of the "facts" about plastic that are cited by the media.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Plants are likely to absorb more carbon dioxide in a changing climate than we thought—here's why
description: The world's vegetation has a remarkable ability to absorb carbon dioxide (CO2) from the air and store it as biomass. In doing so, plants slow down climate change since the CO2 they take up does not contribute to global warming.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: More young people in the UK are living with parents and grandparents: Exploring the benefits and challenges
description: In a recent court case in Pavia, northern Italy, the judge sided with the complainant, a 75-year-old woman, and ordered her adult two sons to move out of her home. The woman's case was a last-ditch attempt to get the men to find what one journalist termed, somewhat elliptically, "more autonomous living arrangements".
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Education linked to better employment prospects upon release from prison
description: Better job prospects. Higher wages. A greater chance of staying out of jail. Those are the key outcomes that we discovered for incarcerated people who get an education while serving their time.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Viewpoint: Being homeless means not being free—as Americans are supposed to be
description: Homelessness is a state of deprivation. Those who are homeless need shelter to be safe; they don't have it. They need a toilet for basic bodily functions; they don't have one. They need a shower to keep clean; they don't have that, either.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Armistice Day counter-protests: How UK government rhetoric and police failings could be linked to far-right violence
description: On Armistice Day 2023, a pro-Palestine march was held in London for the fifth time since the beginning of the Israel-Palestine war. As well as demonstrators looking to join the protest, around 2,000 far-right activists and football hooligans descended on London, too. Their goal, as members of the UK far right put it, was to "defend"" the Cenotaph from the pro-Palestine marchers.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Predicting the response of fungal genes using a new machine-learning approach
description: Signals from the environment set off a cascade of changes that affect different genes in different ways. Therefore, traditionally, it has been difficult to study how such signals influence an organism. In a new study, researchers have developed a machine-learning approach called FUN-PROSE to predict how genes react to different environmental conditions.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: 'Forever contaminant' road salts pose an icy dilemma: Do we protect drivers or our fresh water?
description: As winter approaches, many communities in Canada and around the world arm themselves against icy roads and sidewalks with a time-honored ally: road salt. For decades, applying road salt has been regarded as a simple but vital tool in countering the dangers of slippery road conditions, but the downsides of its use are apparent with implications that extend beyond the cold months.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Researchers: South African university students use AI to help them understand—not to avoid work
description: When ChatGPT was released in November 2022, it sparked many conversations and moral panics. These center on the impact of generative artificial intelligence (AI) on the information environment. People worry that AI chatbots can negatively affect the integrity of creative and academic work, especially since they can produce human-like texts and images.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: A scientist explains an approaching milestone marking the arrival of quantum computers
description: Quantum advantage is the milestone the field of quantum computing is fervently working toward, where a quantum computer can solve problems that are beyond the reach of the most powerful non-quantum, or classical, computers.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Unraveling the surprisingly complex history of crocodiles
description: Crocodiles have a deep and varied evolutionary past. Now researchers are peeling back the layers to find out how the surviving species came to be.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Researchers observe the operating principle of 'promoters' in a catalytic reaction in real-time
description: For the first time, researchers at TU Wien have successfully observed the operating principle of so-called "promoters" in a catalytic reaction in real-time. These promoters play an important role in technology, but so far there is only limited understanding of how they work.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Researchers develop comprehensive genetic map for bison, discover gene responsible for albinism
description: A research team led by scientists from the Texas A&M School of Veterinary Medicine & Biomedical Sciences (VMBS) has developed the most comprehensive genome yet for the North American bison, bringing the animal's genetic roadmap up to date with the latest genome sequencing technology. In doing so, the research team also discovered the gene responsible for albinism in bison.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Korean researchers develop nanomaterial to enable eco-friendly removal of fine dust precursors
description: Over the past decade, fine dust conditions in Korea have worsened, as perceived by the general public, with an increase in the number of days per year featuring high-concentration fine dust. Additionally, the previous maximum fine-dust concentration level has been surpassed. In response, the Korean government has expanded its financial investment in efforts aimed at addressing fine-dust issues.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Team uses gold nanowires to develop wearable sensor that measures two bio-signals
description: A research team led by Professor Sei Kwang Hahn and Dr. Tae Yeon Kim from the Department of Materials Science and Engineering at Pohang University of Science and Technology (POSTECH) used gold nanowires to develop an integrated wearable sensor device that effectively measures and processes two bio-signals simultaneously. Their research findings were featured in Advanced Materials.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Protecting delicate polar ecosystems by mapping biodiversity
description: Polar regions contain vast, undiscovered biodiversity but are both the most threatened and least-understood areas of the world.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Boomerang-like beams of light: Research makes progress toward observing quantum backflow in two dimensions
description: Researchers at the University of Warsaw's Faculty of Physics have superposed two light beams twisted in the clockwise direction to create anti-clockwise twists in the dark regions of the resultant superposition. The results of the research have been published in Optica. This discovery has implications for the study of light-matter interactions and represents a step towards the observation of a peculiar phenomenon known as a quantum backflow.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Concern for the Great Barrier Reef can inspire climate action, but the way we talk about it matters
description: There's no doubt you've heard the Great Barrier Reef is under pressure. The main culprit? Climate change. The main solution? An urgent reduction in greenhouse gas emissions and a shift away from fossil fuels.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Webb reveals new features in heart of Milky Way
description: The latest image from the James Webb Space Telescope shows a portion of the dense center of our galaxy in unprecedented detail, including never-before-seen features astronomers have yet to explain. The star-forming region, named Sagittarius C (Sgr C), is about 300 light-years from the Milky Way's central supermassive black hole, Sagittarius A*.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Adding calcium to soils can help increase organic matter, trap more carbon
description: Farmers add calcium to their soil for many reasons related to increasing crop yields—including regulating pH and improving soil structure.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Investigating the contribution of gamma-ray blazar flares to neutrino flux
description: Blazars belong to the family of active galactic nuclei called quasars. What differentiates them from quasars is that the flares ejected out of these active galactic nuclei are pointed toward the Earth. These flares contain high-energy cosmic rays which are released from the core of these galaxies as jets spanning many light years. Such cosmic rays can interact with photons to produce subatomic particles called neutrinos.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Using recovery capsules to prevent loss of data from balloon-based telescopes
description: An international team of astrophysicists, aerospace engineers and balloonists has found that data recovery capsules are a viable means of ensuring data integrity in the event of loss of flight capabilities or communications abilities in balloon-based telescope projects. In their paper published in a special issue of Aerospace, the group describes their test of four Data Recovery System (DRS) capsules containing 5 TB of telescopic data sent aboard a helium-filled, super-pressurized balloon.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Using tiny traps to study protein interactions can provide new knowledge about difficult-to-treat diseases
description: Proteins that form clumps occur in many difficult-to-treat diseases, such as ALS, Alzheimer's, and Parkinson's. The mechanisms behind how the proteins interact with each other are difficult to study, but now researchers at Chalmers University of Technology, Sweden, have discovered a new method for capturing many proteins in nano-sized traps. Inside the traps, the proteins can be studied in a way that has not been possible before.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Study looks at RNA's solo act on the ever-changing stage of cellular dynamics
description: RNA has been in the limelight for its starring role in cutting-edge vaccine technology, but RNA molecules are also key players in the inner workings of cells.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New method combines synthetic biology with AI in the cell-free quest for new antibiotics
description: The rising resistance of bacteria to antibiotics presents an escalating global health risk. Now, researchers at the Max Planck Institute for Terrestrial Microbiology in Marburg, Germany, have combined synthetic biology and artificial intelligence (AI) to develop a more efficient approach to finding and creating new antimicrobial peptides that are effective against a wide range of bacteria. Their paper is published in the journal Nature Communications.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Half of tested caviar products from Europe are illegal, and some aren't even caviar, finds study
description: Wild caviar, a pricey delicacy made from sturgeon eggs, has been illegal for decades since poaching brought the fish to the brink of extinction. Today, legal, internationally tradeable caviar can only come from farmed sturgeon, and there are strict regulations in place to help protect the species.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Physicists answer question of Supergalactic Plane's absent spiral galaxies
description: Astrophysicists say they have found an answer to why spiral galaxies like our own Milky Way are largely missing from a part of our local universe called the Supergalactic Plane.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: The sound of injustice: Inequitable urban noise impacts people, wildlife
description: Noise is an unseen pollutant with very real health impacts. Like many other forms of pollution, because of systemic injustice, it affects some people more than others. It also affects wildlife.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: These bats use their penis as an 'arm' during sex but not for penetration
description: Mammals usually mate via penetrative sex, but researchers report Nov. 20 in the journal Current Biology that a species of bat, the serotine bat, (Eptesicus serotinus) mates without penetration. This is the first time non-penetrative sex has been documented in a mammal.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Using single-antibodies as a new tool to build bio-circuitry
description: By using single-antibodies, Professor Hirohide Saito (Department of Life Science Frontiers) and his team of researchers, Shodai Komatsu and Assistant Professor Hirohisa Ohno, have developed a novel system to control gene expression in response to any target molecule inside cells, and they have employed it to design various synthetic biological circuits, including one for cell-specific genome editing.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Earth to warm up to 2.9C even with current climate pledges: UN
description: Countries' greenhouse gas-cutting pledges put Earth on track for warming far beyond key limits, potentially up to a catastrophic 2.9 degrees Celsius this century, the UN said Monday, warning "we are out of road".
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Archaeologists uncover Europe's hidden Bronze Age megastructures
description: Archaeologists from University College Dublin, working with colleagues from Serbia and Slovenia, have uncovered a previously unknown network of massive sites in the heart of Europe that could explain the emergence of the continent's Bronze Age megaforts—the largest prehistoric constructions seen prior to the Iron Age.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Women are leading the fight to stop climate change
description: Over the past few years, international climate policy has been shaped largely by a close-knit group of politicians in the twilight of their careers. Now leaders from beyond the traditional U.S.-Europe-China power center—some new to the international stage, others already veterans—are emerging. And women are at the forefront.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New computer code for mechanics of tissues and cells in three dimensions
description: Biological materials are made of individual components, including tiny motors that convert fuel into motion. This creates patterns of movement, and the material shapes itself with coherent flows by constant consumption of energy. Such continuously driven materials are called active matter.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: AI-powered crab gender identification: Revolutionizing fishery management and conservation
description: When winter comes to Japan, fishermen in the northern regions set out to capture one of the most anticipated seasonal delicacies: the horsehair crab. Known locally as "kegani" and bearing the scientific name Erimacrus isenbeckii, this species of crustacean is highly sought after throughout the country.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: NASA mission excels at spotting greenhouse gas emission sources
description: Since launching 16 months ago, the EMIT imaging spectrometer aboard the International Space Station has shown an ability to detect more than just surface minerals.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Climate change threatens cereal crop yields: Study
description: The effects of climate change pose a major challenge for cereal production in many regions. In a study published in Nature Reviews Earth & Environment, ZALF scientists have investigated how warmer temperatures, increased carbon dioxide levels and changes in water availability affect globally important cereals such as wheat, maize, millet, sorghum and rice.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Microbiome development: Bacteria lay the foundations for their descendants
description: The microbiome (the symbiotic community of microbial organisms of a host) is of existential importance for the functioning of every plant and animal, including human beings. A research team from Düsseldorf and Kiel headed by Heinrich Heine University Düsseldorf (HHU) has now used the example of the sea anemone Nematostella vectenis to investigate how the microbiome develops together with the host.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Research reveals rare metal could offer revolutionary switch for future quantum devices
description: Quantum scientists have discovered a rare phenomenon that could hold the key to creating a 'perfect switch' in quantum devices which flips between being an insulator and a superconductor.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Coastal river deltas threatened by more than climate change, study shows
description: Worldwide, coastal river deltas are home to more than half a billion people, supporting fisheries, agriculture, cities, and fertile ecosystems. In a unique study covering 49 deltas globally, researchers from Lund University and Utrecht University have identified the most critical risks to deltas in the future. The research shows that deltas face multiple risks, and that population growth and poor environmental governance might pose bigger threats than climate change to the sustainability of Asian and African deltas, in particular.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Gold nanoparticles and light could melt venous malformations away
description: Venous malformations—tissues made up largely of abnormally shaped veins—are often difficult to treat, especially when located in sensitive areas like the eyes, face, and genitourinary organs. In the worst cases, the lesions are disfiguring and can crush or obstruct surrounding tissues, cause bleeding and clotting, interfere with breathing or vision, or impair circulation.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Researchers reveal how mycorrhizal species regulate plant-soil carbon in forests
description: In a study published in Nature Climate Change, researchers led by Prof. Zhu Jiaojun from the Institute of Applied Ecology of the Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS) have reported a mycorrhizae-mediated trade-off between plant biomass and soil carbon sequestration in forest ecosystems under nitrogen deposition and warming conditions.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Study of crossbred butterflies suggests multiple genes involved in hybrid animal sterility
description: When animals of two different species mate, their hybrid offspring can be unhealthy or sterile. Often, only one sex is affected.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Research provides new methods to improve capture rates of ground-dwelling arthropods using pitfall trapping
description: Pitfall traps are commonly used for capturing ground-dwelling arthropods, particularly beetles, ants, and spiders. The efficiency of a pitfall trapping system is significantly influenced by the quantity and size of traps, the spatial distribution of traps across the sampling area, and the movement characteristics of arthropods.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: To study radioactive neptunium and plutonium, researchers establish a novel chemistry
description: Oxidation is the process where atoms lose electrons during a chemical reaction. Among the radioactive elements, neptunium and plutonium are much harder to oxidize than uranium.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: High-power fiber lasers emerge as a pioneering technology
description: Optical scientists have found a new way to significantly increase the power of fiber lasers while maintaining their beam quality, making them a future key defense technology against low-cost drones and for use in other applications such as remote sensing.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: 'Teenage galaxies' are unusually hot, glowing with unexpected elements
description: Similar to human teenagers, teenage galaxies are awkward, experience growth spurts and enjoy heavy metal—nickel, that is.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Reshaping protein design with function-first, AI-guided engineering
description: A significant step forward in protein design from Generate Biomedicines, Massachusetts, has developed an AI that can generate feasible protein structures and predict the potential functionality of the proteins generated.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Why purple-crowned fairy-wrens engage in cooperative breeding
description: A team of biologists at Monash University, working with a colleague from Wageningen University, has found an explanation for why purple-crowned fairy wrens engage in cooperative breeding. In their paper published in the journal Royal Society Open Science, the group describes their study of the birds in the wild.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Global one-day temperature spikes above 2C for first time: EU monitor
description: The global average temperature on Friday was more than two degrees Celsius hotter than pre-industrial levels for the first time on record, Europe's Copernicus climate monitor said Monday.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: 'Naked Clams': Aquaculture system hopes to turn marine pest into nutritious seafood
description: Researchers hoping to rebrand a marine pest as a nutritious food have developed the world's first system of farming shipworms, which they have renamed "Naked Clams." These long, white saltwater clams are the world's fastest-growing bivalve and can reach 30cm long in just six months. They do this by burrowing into waste wood and converting it into highly-nutritious protein.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Frustration as latest talks on global plastic treaty close
description: The latest negotiations toward a global plastic treaty concluded late Sunday with disagreement about how the pact should work and frustration from environment groups over delays and lack of progress.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: At least 21 dead in torrential Dominican Republic rains
description: At least 21 people, including three children, died after heavy rainfall inundated the Dominican Republic over the weekend, authorities said Sunday, warning the downpours were linked to worsening climate change.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: World's richest 1% emit as much carbon as bottom two-thirds: report
description: The richest one percent of the global population are responsible for the same amount of carbon emissions as the world's poorest two-thirds, or five billion people, according to an analysis published Sunday by the nonprofit Oxfam International.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Australians vote on name for home-made moon rover
description: Australians began voting Monday on a name for the country's first home-made moon rover, with a shortlist including "Mateship", "Roo-ver" and "Kakirra"—an Indigenous word for the Earth's satellite.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
